docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since Pavlov trained dogs to salivate for meat powder at the sound of a bell, psychologists have used the principles of classical conditioning to study how animals and humans learn. But only recently have they been able to peer into the brain and watch that learning take place.

headline.main: Studying Modern-Day Pavlov's Dogs, of the Human Variety

docs.abstract: Dr Jay A Gottfried, Wellcome department of neuroimaging science postdoctoral fellow at University College London, leads research published in journal Science that follows human Pavlovian behavior utilizing brain scanning functional MRI's; study of 13 subjects not only backed Pavlov's theories of classial conditioning, but also supported behavioral phenomenon of selective satiation, which allows humans to entertain idea of dessert after already filling meal; research could aid in better understanding of brain's effects on people with eating disorders (S)

docs.abstract: Authors Dr Justin Richardson, Columbia University and Cornell University assistant psychiatry professor, and Dr Mark A Schuster, UCLA associate professor, have written book Everything You Never Wanted Your Kids to Know About Sex, which aims to help parents to answer difficult questions and cope with attitudes of young adults about sex; advice on preschool-age approaches as well as differences in approach for girls and boys discussed; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: People appear to alter their speaking tempos unconsciously to match the speech patterns of those around them, a new study shows. And musicians do the same thing when playing, but are even better at it, the study says. ''It's not like you completely change who you are in terms of the way you speak,'' said the lead author, Dr. Melissa K. Jungers, a psychologist at Ohio State University. ''It's kind of like you get pulled in the direction of whoever you're speaking with.''
docs.abstract: Dr Melissa K Jungers, Ohio State University psychologist, leads study, published in journal Cognitive Processing, which shows that when communicating people will alter their speech pattern to fit person they are speaking with; musicians studied likewise change tempo to match that of those performing independently around them; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Young children who snore are also likely to suffer from asthma and nighttime cough, complicating the question of which condition should be treated, a new study says. Writing in the current journal Chest, Australian researchers said their survey found that snoring was fairly common among children from 2 to 5 years old.

headline.main: Snoring in a Nursery: What to Do

docs.abstract: Lucy R Lu, University of Sydney researcher and lead author of study published in journal Chest, finds link between children who snore and nighttime cough and asthma; 10% of children from 2 to 5 years of age were found to snore and 62% of snorers suffer nighttime cough; suggests treatment of one symptom could effect all three conditions as they are interrelated; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adults are often quick to tell college students: ''Enjoy yourselves. This is the best time of your lives.'' But for an increasing number of students, the college experience is marred by chronic anxiety, stress and distress. College counselors report a sharp increase in the need and demand for mental health services, and that can sometimes result in long waiting lists, making the troubled students' problems even worse.

headline.main: Hello to College Joys: Keep Stress Off Campus

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column gives advice to college students about identifying causes and treating stress; discusses various stress-inducing situations; recalls her own experience coping emotionally during freshman and sophomore years; describes effects of alcohol, tobacco and food on emotional well being; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 13 percent of heart bypass patients need more hospital treatment for complications of the surgery, researchers report. The study, led by Dr. Edward L. Hannan of the School of Public Health at the State University of New York at Albany, was based on a review of bypass operations performed in New York over a one-year period.
docs.abstract: Dr Edward L Hannan, State University of New York (Albany) School of Public Health researcher, finds nearly 13% of heart bypass patients return to hospital after surgery to treat complications of procedure; study, published in Journal of American Medical Association, indicates that 28% of those readmitted are for infection and hospitals performing fewest bypass operations have highest readmittance rates (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I went to see a patient in the intensive care unit. A former prisoner of war from World War II, he was in the clutches of a fever that had lasted several weeks, and he had started to deteriorate. ''He's getting better,'' his wife insisted when I spoke with her, gently combing his straight white hair, even after he stopped following simple commands.
docs.abstract: Cases article discusses fever of at least 101 degrees lasting minimum of three weeks and defying hospital investigation; notes such fever is labeled fever of unknown origin; explores benefits of suppressing fever in general and use of analyzing fever to pinpoint ailment; in 2001, Drs David Aronoff and Eric Neilson, Vanderbilt University infectious disease specialists, wrote in American Journal of Medicine that benefits of efforts to reduce core fever in patients are unclear (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was not until two days before he was to appear on television in Australia to talk about his book that Benjamin Polis, 19, told his girlfriend that he had attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and had, by the way, written an autobiographical account about it. Embarrassed and stigmatized throughout his life, he found it difficult to concede that he was different, even to his closest friends. But the success of his book, ''Only a Mother Could Love Him,'' has changed a lot. Mr. Polis, who as a child cried daily, begging his mother not to send him to school, is now, at 21, speaking out about A.D.H.D., in an effort to help teenagers who have it understand their impulsive, hyperactive and, at times, uncontrollable behavior, as well as to help parents handle their children better.

headline.main: Attention Disorder Advice, by One Who Knows

docs.abstract: Book Only Mother Could Love Him, written by nineteen-year-old Benjamin Polis, is autobiographical account of growing up with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; 3 to 5 percent of children have ADHD, or ADD, and by sharing his story, he hopes to help both children suffering with disorder and parents frustrated by day-to-day living with afflicted children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who take other painkillers along with aspirin could be losing the heart benefits of the aspirin, researchers said today. Drugs like ibuprofen may be competing with aspirin in the body if people use them daily to control arthritis pain, for instance, the researchers warned.
docs.abstract: Dr Tobias Kurth, Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital (Boston) researcher, publishes study in journal Circulation that shows use of other painkillers along with aspirin therapy can inhibit effectiveness of aspirin in reducing heart attack and stroke; findings looked at records of 22,071 male doctors participating in Physicians' Health Study over course of five years; cox-2 inhibitors, such as acetaminophen, do not appear to alter aspirin's beneficial effects (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hitting a soccer ball with the head, even repeatedly over a long time, is unlikely to cause injury, despite some recent concerns, an editorial in the medical journal BMJ argues. The item was prompted by a ruling from a British coroner who attributed the death of a 59-year-old retired soccer player last year to ''industrial disease.'' The player, Jeff Astle, died as a result of repeated blows to the head from soccer balls, the coroner said.
docs.abstract: BMJ medical journal editorial by Dr Paul R McCrory, University of Melbourne (Australia), is critical of British coroner who ruled retired soccer player Jeff Astle's death was result of repeated soccer ball blows to head; contends heading soccer ball does not create enough impact to cause neurological injury; acknowledges head to head collisions could cause serious injury; cartoon (S)
